description.0: The Pearson correlation coefficient, also known as linear correlation or product-moment correlation coefficient, is a statistical measure used to quantify the linear relationship between two quantitative variables. It is one of the most commonly used correlation statistics and provides information about the strength and direction of the relationship between variables.
description.1: The Pearson correlation coefficient varies between -1 and 1:
description.2: A value of -1 indicates a perfectly negative linear correlation, meaning that as one variable increases, the other decreases in an inverse linear relationship.
description.3: A value of 1 indicates a perfectly positive linear correlation, meaning that as one variable increases, the other also increases in a direct linear relationship.
description.4: A value of 0 indicates that there is no linear correlation between the variables, which implies that there is no linear relationship between them.
description.5: The calculation of the Pearson correlation coefficient is based on the covariances and standard deviations of the two variables. Mathematically, it is calculated as follows:
description.7: are the values of the two variables in each observation.
description.8: are the stockings of the two variables, respectively.
description.9: The Pearson correlation coefficient is a useful tool to analyze the linear relationship between two variables and determine if an association exists between them. It is widely used in various areas, such as scientific research, economics, psychology, sociology and many others, to understand how two variables behave together. However, it is important to note that the Pearson correlation coefficient only measures the linear relationship and does not capture other types of non-linear relationships between the variables.

text.0: The AUTO MPG dataset was taken from the StatLib library maintained at Carnegie Mellon University. The dataset was used at the 1983 American Statistical Association Exposition.
text.1:
The term "Auto MPG" refers to miles per gallon, a unit of fuel efficiency measurement commonly used in the United States. This measure indicates how many miles a vehicle can travel on one gallon of fuel. However, "Auto MPG" is an English term and there is no direct translation in Spanish.

In Spanish, terms such as "consumo de combustible" or "rendimiento de combustible" are often used to refer to the fuel efficiency of a car. These terms indicate how many kilometres or miles a vehicle can travel on one litre or gallon of fuel, respectively.

It is important to note that different countries use different units of measurement for fuel consumption. For example, in some places the litre per 100 kilometres travelled (L/100 km) is used to indicate fuel efficiency.

list.2: displacement: This is another attribute of the vehicle which has a quantitative continuous value describing the engine displacement
list.3: horsepower: This attribute tells about the horsepower of a car and is a continuous valued variable
list.4: weight: This refers to the weight of each car which is a continuous valued quantitative variable
list.6: model year: The year the model was released is mentioned in this attribute
list.7: origin: The origin attribute has 3 discrete values. 1 refers to cars made in USA, 2 for Europe and 3 for Asia
list.8: car name: This is the name of the car in string

text.0: It is a data set from the University of Wisconsin Hospital related to breast cancer. This data set is useful for the prediction and discrimination of a breast cancer tumor, differentiating whether it is benign or not.
text.1: Each record represents follow-up data for a breast cancer case. These are cases treated since 1984 by Dr. Wolberg, he only includes those cases that present invasive breast cancer and without evidence of metastasis.
text.2: The first 30 characteristics are calculated from a digitized image of a fine needle aspiration (FNAB) of the breast mass, these data describe the characteristics of the cell nuclei present in the image, some images can be found in <link1>cs wisc</link1>
text.3: The file <kbd>wdbc.csv</kbd> corresponds to the diagnostic data set and <kbd>wpbc.csv</kbd> corresponds to the prognostic data set.

list.0: ID number
list.1: Outcome (R = recur, N = nonrecur)
list.2: Time (recurrence time if field 2 = R, disease-free time if field 2 = N)
list.3: 4-33 Ten real-valued features are computed for each cell nucleus:
list.4: radius (mean of distances from center to points on the perimeter)
list.10: concavity (severity of concave portions of the contour)
list.11: concave points (number of concave portions of the contour)

text.0: The data set includes data on the academic performance of students from two Portuguese schools. The data includes demographic, social characteristics, student grades, etc. Two sets of data are included, one with the performance of two different subjects: Mathematics (mat) and Portuguese language (por).
text.1: The data set contains multivariate type data, real type attributes, 649 instances, and 12 distinct attributes.
text.2: Important note: The target attribute G3 has a strong correlation with the attributes G2 and G1. This occurs because G3 is the grade for the last year (issued in the 3rd period), while G1 and G2 correspond to the grades for the 1st and 2nd period. It is more difficult to predict G3 without G2 and G1, but such a prediction is much more useful.
text.3: The file <kbd>student-por.csv</kbd> corresponds to the data set of Portuguese student grades and <kbd>student-mat.csv</kbd> corresponds to the data set of mathematics student grades.

text.0: The two data sets are related, as they include the red wine and Portuguese white wine variants. Said data set only includes physicochemical (inputs) and sensory (outputs) variables, the data set does not include data on grape types, wine brand or wine sales price.
text.1: The dataset contains multivariate type data, real type attributes, 4898 instances, and 12 distinct attributes.
text.2: This data set can be used for classification or regression tasks. The classes are ordered, although the data set is unbalanced.
text.3: The <kbd> wine-qualy-red.csv </kbd> file corresponds to the red wine data set and <kbd> wine-qualy-white.csv </kbd> corresponds to the white wine data set.

description.link: For more information about this data set visit the repository <link1>archive.ics.uci.edu</link1>.

list.0: Fixed Acidity: Fixed acidity refers to the concentration of non-volatile acids in wine, mainly tartaric acid. It contributes to the freshness and stability of the wine.
list.1: Volatile Acidity: Volatile acidity refers to the concentration of volatile acids, such as acetic acid, which can give an unpleasant taste if present in excess.
list.2: Citric Acid: Citric acid is one of the natural organic acids present in wine. It can influence the flavor and freshness of the wine.
list.3: Residual Sugar: It is the amount of sugar that remains in the wine after fermentation. A wine can be dry (little residual sugar) or sweet (more residual sugar).
list.4: Chlorides: The concentration of chlorides in wine can affect its flavor and aroma, and high levels can indicate problems in production.
list.5: Free Sulfur Dioxide: Sulfur dioxide is a common preservative in wine that helps prevent oxidation and the growth of unwanted microorganisms.
list.6: Total Sulfur Dioxide: Represents the sum of free sulfur dioxide and sulfur dioxide bound to other molecules in the wine. It is also related to the conservation of wine.
list.7: Density: Density refers to the mass of the wine per unit of volume. It can provide information on alcohol and sugar concentration.
list.8: pH: The pH measures the acidity or alkalinity of the wine. A low pH indicates acidity, while a high pH indicates alkalinity. It can influence flavor perception.
list.9: Sulphates: Sulfates are additives that are sometimes used in wine production. They can influence the stability and aroma of the wine.
list.10: Alcohol: The concentration of alcohol in wine can vary and affects both the flavor and mouthfeel.
list.11: Quality: This is the overall quality score of the wine, generally on a scale of 0 to 10, with higher values indicating better quality wines as assessed by tasters.

intro.0:
Bar graphs are a visual representation that shows the comparison of different categories or groups using rectangular bars.
This type of graph uses the length or height of bars to represent the magnitude or quantity of a specific variable.
intro.1:
In a bar graph, the horizontal axis represents the categories or groups, while the vertical axis shows the magnitude or frequency of the variable being analyzed.
Each category has an individual bar, and the length or height of the bar is proportional to the corresponding value or quantity.
The bars can be horizontal or vertical, depending on the orientation of the chart.
intro.2: Bar charts have several notable features and applications:

list.0:
Category Comparison: Bar charts are ideal for visually comparing different categories or groups.
By looking at the bars, it is possible to quickly identify differences in magnitude or quantity between categories.
list.1:
Representation of categorical or discrete data: Bar graphs are suitable for representing categorical or discrete variables.
Each bar represents a specific category and the height or length of the bar shows the magnitude or quantity associated with that category.
list.2:
Category Sorting: Categories in a bar chart can be sorted based on different criteria, such as alphabetical order, order of magnitude, or any other logical order.
This allows specific patterns or trends to be highlighted between categories.
list.3:
Displaying frequencies or percentages: Bar graphs are also used to represent frequencies or percentages.
In this case, the height or length of the bars represents the proportion or percentage corresponding to each category.
list.4:
Effective presentation: Bar charts are an effective tool for presenting information in a clear and concise manner.
Their simple structure and ability to highlight differences between categories make them widely used in reports, presentations, and documents.
list.5:
Bar charts are an effective way to visualize and compare categories or groups based on their magnitude or quantity.
They are ideal for representing categorical or discrete data and allow for effective presentation of information.
Their simplicity and ability to highlight differences make them a commonly used tool in data analysis and communication.

end.0:
Bar charts are an effective way to visualize and compare categories or groups based on their magnitude or quantity.
They are ideal for representing categorical or discrete data and allow for effective presentation of information.
Their simplicity and ability to highlight differences make them a commonly used tool in data analysis and communication.

intro.0:
Box plots, also known as box-and-whisker plots or boxplots, are a visual representation used to show the distribution and statistical summaries of a set of numerical data.
This type of chart is based on a rectangle that represents the interquartile range (IQR), where the center line indicates the median and the extended lines, known as whiskers, represent the range of
values beyond the IQR.
intro.1:
In a box chart, the rectangle is drawn vertically or horizontally, and is delimited by two lines, one at the bottom and one at the top.
The line in the middle of the rectangle represents the median, which is the value that divides the ordered data into two equal parts.
The whiskers extend from the edges of the rectangle toward the extreme values, with a length determined by the variability of the data.
intro.2: Box charts have several notable features and applications:

list.0:
Statistical summary: Box charts provide a visual summary of the key statistics of a data set.
In addition to the median, you can also display quartiles (Q1 and Q3), which divide the data into four equal parts, and outliers, which are displayed as dots or asterisks outside the whiskers.
list.1:
Identification of asymmetries and outliers: By observing a Box type chart, it is possible to identify asymmetries in the distribution of the data.
If the whiskers are not the same length, it may indicate an asymmetry towards one of the ends.
Additionally, outliers outside the whiskers can be easily highlighted.
list.2:
Comparison between groups or categories: Box charts are also used to compare the distribution of data between different groups or categories.
By overlaying multiple boxplots on the same graph, it is possible to visualize differences in medians, interquartile ranges, and the presence of outliers between groups.
list.3:
Detect biases and distributions: Box graphs allow you to visually identify whether the data distribution is symmetrical or skewed towards one extreme.
If the center line of the rectangle is not in the middle, it may indicate a bias towards the opposite direction.
list.4:
Visualization of dispersions: In addition to providing information about the central position and variability of the data, box charts also allow you to visualize the dispersion and variability of the data in a single graph.
This can be useful to get a quick idea of the overall distribution and variability of the data.

end.0:
Box plots are a useful tool for visualizing the distribution, statistical summaries, and variability of a numerical data set.
They allow you to identify asymmetries, outliers and compare distributions between groups.
Their concise and effective visual representation makes them a commonly used tool in data analysis and communication.

intro.0:
Histogram graphs are a visual representation used to show the distribution of numerical or continuous data.
This type of graph is based on a set of adjacent rectangular bars, where the width of each bar represents a range of values and the height of the bar indicates the frequency or number of observations within that range.
interval.
intro.1:
In a histogram-type graph, the horizontal axis is used to represent the range of values of the variable under study, divided into intervals or bins.
The vertical axis represents the frequency or number of observations in each interval.
The height of each bar shows how many observations fall within that specific interval.
intro.2: Histogram-type charts have several notable features and applications:

list.0:
Viewing distributions: Histograms allow you to view the shape and distribution of numerical data.
They can show whether the data follows a symmetric, skewed, multimodal, or uniform distribution.
list.1:
Identifying Outliers: By looking at a histogram, it is possible to identify outliers or extreme values that are outside the range of the majority of the data.
These values will be represented as isolated bars or as bars that extend beyond the main range of values.
list.2:
Trend and pattern analysis: Histograms can reveal patterns and trends in data.
For example, a distribution skewed left or right indicates asymmetry in the data, while a normal distribution shows approximate symmetry.
list.3:
Comparison of groups or categories: Histograms can also be used to compare the distribution of data between different groups or categories.
By overlaying multiple histograms on the same graph, it is possible to visualize the differences and similarities between groups.
list.4:
Density Estimation: In addition to showing absolute frequency, histograms can also provide a visual estimate of the probability density of the data.
By normalizing the heights of the bars, it is possible to obtain a relative representation of the probability of occurrence of the values in each interval.

end.0:
Histogram-type graphs are a useful tool for visualizing the distribution and patterns of numerical data.
They allow you to identify outliers, analyze trends and compare distributions between groups.
Their clear and concise visual representation makes them an effective tool for communicating information about data distribution in an understandable way.

intro.0:
Line graphs, also known as series graphs or trend graphs, are a visual representation that shows the relationship and evolution of data over time or a continuous variable.
These graphs are constructed by plotting data points in a Cartesian coordinate system, where each point represents a measurement or a specific value of the variable on the vertical axis as a function of time or the variable.
independent on the horizontal axis.
intro.1:
In a line graph, data points are connected by straight lines, creating a series of connected points.
These lines allow you to visualize the trajectory and pattern of change of the data over time or of the independent variable.
The slope of the line can indicate an increasing or decreasing trend, while variations in the direction and shape of the line can reveal additional patterns in the data.
intro.2: Line type charts have several notable features and applications:

list.0:
Representation of trends: Line-type graphs are especially useful for showing trends and changes over time.
They can reveal patterns of growth, decline, or fluctuation in data as they occur over time.
list.1:
Identification of changes and variations: By observing a line graph, it is possible to identify abrupt changes or variations in the data.
These changes may indicate significant events or factors that influence the measured variable.
list.2:
Comparing Multiple Series: Line charts also allow you to compare multiple data series on a single chart.
This is useful for analyzing and visualizing the relationship between different variables as they evolve over time.
list.3:
Seasonality and cycle analysis: If the data exhibits seasonal or cyclical patterns, line graphs can help identify and analyze these patterns.
This can be useful in fields such as economics, meteorology, and sales analysis, where there are recurring fluctuations in data.
list.4:
Forecasting and projection: Line type charts are also used to make forecasts and projections based on historical data.
By looking at past trends, it is possible to infer and predict how data will behave in the future.

end.0:
Line graphs are a valuable tool for visualizing and analyzing the relationship and evolution of data over time or a continuous variable.
They allow you to identify trends, changes and patterns in the data, as well as make comparisons and forecasts.
Their clear and concise visual representation makes them an effective tool for communicating complex information in an understandable way.

intro.0:
Pie or pie charts are a visual representation that shows the proportion of different categories or parts in relation to the whole.
These graphs are based on a circle divided into sectors, where each sector represents a specific category and its relative size reflects the proportion that category represents in the data set.
intro.1:
In a pie chart, the full circle represents 100% or the total data.
Each sector is shown as a portion of the circle and is labeled with the name or label corresponding to the category it represents.
The sector angle measure is proportional to the proportion that category has in the data set.
intro.2: Pie charts have several notable features and applications:

list.0:
Representation of proportions: Pie charts are ideal for representing proportions and percentages.
They allow you to quickly visualize the relative contribution of each category in the total data set.
list.1:
Identifying Dominant Categories: The relative sizes of the slices in the pie chart help to easily identify the dominant or most significant categories.
The largest sectors indicate the categories that have a greater proportion or contribution in relation to the others.
list.2:
Comparison between categories: While pie charts are useful for showing the proportions of categories, they can be limited in making accurate comparisons between them.
This is because human perception can have difficulty accurately evaluating differences in angle or sector sizes.
However, the relative comparison between sector sizes can still provide general information about the proportions between categories.
list.3:
Representing Categorical Data: Pie charts are especially useful for representing categorical data, where the categories are mutually exclusive and have no inherent order.
For example, they can be used to show the percentage distribution of income across different expense categories.
list.4:
Improving Visual Presentation: Pie charts are commonly used in presentations and documents to communicate information in a visually appealing and easily understandable way.
The circular shape and colors used can quickly capture attention and highlight the proportional relationships between categories.

end.0:
Pie charts are an effective tool for representing proportions and percentages of categories in a data set.
They allow the dominant categories to be identified and provide an attractive visual presentation.
However, it is important to note its limitations in terms of accurate comparison between categories and its focus on categorical data.

intro.0:
A scatter plot, also known as a dot plot or scatter plot in English, is a visual representation that uses Cartesian coordinates to show the relationship between two variables.
In this type of graph, data is represented as individual points in two-dimensional space, where each point represents a pair of values corresponding to the two variables.
intro.1:
In a scatter plot, the horizontal axis is usually assigned to the independent variable, while the vertical axis is assigned to the dependent variable.
Each point on the graph represents an individual observation and its position on the graph is determined by the values it has for both variables.
The relative location of the points on the graph reveals patterns and relationships between the two variables.
intro.2: Scatter charts have several notable applications and features:

list.0:
Relationship between variables: Scatter graphs allow you to analyze the relationship between two variables.
They can show whether there is a positive correlation (the points tend to cluster in an upward direction), a negative correlation (the points tend to cluster in a downward direction), or a lack of correlation (the points do not show a definite pattern).
list.1:
Identifying trends: A scatter plot can reveal trends or patterns in the data.
By looking at the general direction of the points, it is possible to identify whether there is a linear, nonlinear, or even a curvilinear relationship between the variables.
list.2:
Outlier Detection: Scatter plots can help identify outliers or extremes in data.
These points stand out and are far from the main grouping, suggesting unusual or exceptional observations that may require additional analysis.
list.3:
Analysis of clusters or groups: If the points in the scatter plot group together or form distinct patterns, this may indicate the presence of clusters or groups.
This can be useful in data segmentation or classification analysis.
list.4:
Multidimensional data visualization: By using additional colors or point sizes, scatter plots can also represent additional information in two-dimensional space.
This allows multidimensional data to be viewed more intuitively.

end.0:
Scatter plots are a powerful tool for exploring and visualizing the relationship between two variables.
They allow you to identify patterns, trends, and outliers in data, and are useful in various applications, such as correlation analysis, cluster detection, and multidimensional data visualization.

time-series-plots.title: Time Series Plots

intro.0:
A time series chart is a visual representation of data that is collected and recorded at regular intervals over time.
These charts are widely used in various disciplines, such as economics, finance, meteorology, engineering, and many others, to analyze and understand how data changes over time.
intro.1:
The horizontal axis of the graph represents time, while the vertical axis shows the data values being observed or recorded.
Data points are connected with lines, allowing patterns and trends to be identified over time.
intro.2: Time series charts offer several advantages and practical applications:

list.0:
Trend Analysis: Time series graphs allow you to identify and analyze long-term trends in data.
This can be useful for predicting how data will behave in the future and making informed decisions.
list.1:
Identifying seasonal patterns: In many data sets, there are seasonal patterns that repeat regularly over time, such as holiday sales or seasonal fluctuations in agricultural production.
Time series charts help identify these seasonal patterns and understand their impact on the data.
list.2:
Detection of changes and anomalies: By observing a time series graph, it is possible to identify abrupt changes or anomalies in the data.
These changes may indicate important or unusual events that require further investigation and analysis.
list.3:
Modeling and forecasting: Time series graphs are a fundamental tool for developing models and forecasts.
By looking at past patterns, it is possible to build mathematical or statistical models that capture relationships and allow predictions about the future.
list.4:
Comparative Analysis: Time series charts are also used to compare different sets of data that are collected during the same time period.
This can help identify differences, similarities and relationships between the observed variables.

end.0:
Time series charts are an essential tool for analyzing and understanding how data changes over time.
They provide valuable information on trends, seasonal patterns, changes and forecasts, enabling informed decisions and comparative analysis.

intro.0:
A violin plot is a visual representation that combines features of a box-and-whisker plot with a probability density function.
This type of chart provides a detailed view of the distribution of the data and allows you to compare multiple groups or categories in a single chart.
intro.1:
The appearance of a violin chart resembles the shape of a violin, hence its name.
It has a center line that represents the median of the data and two shaded areas on either side that represent the probability density distribution.
These shaded areas of symmetry along the center line to reflect the symmetry or asymmetry of the data.
intro.2:
The violin plot shape provides information about the distribution of the data.
For example, a wider violin plot in a particular section indicates a higher density of data in that area, while a narrower section indicates a lower density.
Additionally, violin charts can have multiple violins grouped or overlapping to allow visual comparison of different groups or categories.
intro.3: Violin charts have several practical applications:

list.0:
Comparing Distributions: Violin plots allow you to compare data distributions between different groups or categories.
This is useful for identifying differences or similarities in the shape, dispersion, and trends of the data.
list.1:
Identifying Outliers: Violin plots provide visual information about the presence of outliers or extremes in the data.
These values are represented as points outside the shaded areas and may indicate unusual observations that may require additional analysis.
list.2:
Probability Density Visualization: Violin plots also provide a graphical representation of the probability density of the data.
This allows areas of high or low density, as well as possible biases or asymmetries in the distribution, to be easily identified.
list.3:
Effective data communication: Violin charts are an effective way to communicate complex information about the distribution of data in a visually appealing way.
They can summarize information concisely and help convey important patterns and features to a non-technical audience.

end.0:
Violin plots are a useful tool for visualizing and comparing data distributions.
They allow you to analyze the shape, dispersion, symmetry and presence of outliers in the data, and are especially useful when comparison between multiple groups or categories is required.
Their attractive and concise graphical representation makes them an effective tool for communicating complex information in an understandable way.

details-edit-layers.title: Editor of the Layers
details-edit-layers.text-0: You can edit the layers of the neural network, you can add as many as you want by pressing the "Add layer" button at the start or at the end.

list.0:
Layer neurons:
Each neuron in a layer has a set of associated weights that weigh its output value.
We can edit the number of neurons in the layer.
list.1:
Activation function:
The activation function of a neuron refers to the mathematical function that calculates its output. We can edit the activation function of the neurons of each layer.

details-hyper-parameters-editor.title: Hyperparameter editor
details-hyper-parameters-editor.text-0:
The necessary general parameters can be edited for the creation of the model.
These parameters are:

list.0:
Learning rate:
Value between 0 and 100 which indicates the percentage of the weight weights.
list.1:
Number of epochs:
Number of times the network training set (the greatest number, it takes longer to train).
list.2:
Test set size:
Percentage of the data set that will be used for model tests (test data). The rest of the data will be used for network training (training data).
list.3:
Optimizer:
It is a function that is used to adjust the weights of the network.
list.4:
loss function:
It is a error calculation method to measure model efficiency during training.
list.5:
Metric function:
It is the average evaluation used to assess the performance of an machine learning model with test data.

list.0:
Learning rate:
The learning rate is a parameter that determines how much the weights of the neural network should be updated depending on the error calculated during training.
list.1:
Number of epochs:
The number of epochs refers to the number of times the training data is presented to the neural network during the training process. Each iteration implies an update of the weights of the network as a function of the calculated error.
list.2:
Test set size:
The size of the test set refers to the amount of data used to evaluate the performance of the neural network after training. This dataset is not used in the training of the neural network and is used to measure the network capacity to generalize new data.
list.3:
Optimizer:
The optimizer is an algorithm used to update the weights of the neural network depending on the error calculated during training. Some examples of optimizers are the descent of the stochastic gradient (SGD), the ADAM and the ADAM.
list.4:
Loss function:
The loss function is a measure of the error between the neural network predictions and the real outputs. It is used to optimize the neural network during training and there are different loss functions, such as cross entropy and middle quadratic error.

details-create-and-train-models.title: Create and train model
details-create-and-train-models.text-0: Once all previous fields have been filled we can create the model by pressing the "Create and train model" button.
details-create-and-train-models.text-1:
If we have trained the model with the metric function Accuracy two graphs will appear in the visor. The most relevant to us is that below, since at tensorflow.js, ac and Val_acc are evaluation metrics commonly used in training models of neural networks.
Acc represents the precision (Accuracy) of the model in the training dataset. The precision is defined as the number of correct predictions divided by the total number of predictions.
Val_acc represents the precision of the model in the validation dataset. Validation is used to evaluate the model capacity to generalize new data that has not been seen during training.
details-create-and-train-models.text-2: The validation precision is important to detect the over juste ( over fitting ) of the model, which occurs when the model fits too much to training data and does not generalize well to new data.

details-export-models.title: Export model
details-export-models.text-0: If we have created the model correctly an entry will be added to the table of models generated, we are allowed to export the models generated and save them locally.

details-prediction.title: Prediction
details-prediction.text-0: The final form allows us to select the main characteristics used to determine the class.
details-prediction.text-1: By pressing the "See result" button, the prediction of its output class is obtained from the input characteristics of the element.

details-edit-layers-more-info.title: Additional information layers
details-edit-layers-more-info.text-0: Additionally, there are two more layers that are common to the rest of the machine learning networks focused on image classification.

list.0:
dense
Creates a dense (fully connected) layer.
list.1:
dropout
Dropout consists in randomly setting a fraction rate of input units to 0 at each update during training time, which helps prevent overfitting.
list.2:
embedding
Maps positive integers (indices) into dense vectors of fixed size. eg. [[4], [20]] -> [[0.25, 0.1], [0.6, -0.2]]
list.3:
flatten
A Flatten layer flattens each batch in its inputs to 1D (making the output 2D).
list.4:
permute
Permutes the dimensions of the input according to a given pattern.
list.5:
repeatVector
Repeats the input n times in a new dimension.
list.6:
reshape
Reshapes an input to a certain shape.

Optimizer:
The optimizer is an algorithm used to update the weights of the neural network depending on the error calculated during training. Some examples of optimizers are the descent of the stochastic gradient (SGD), the ADAM and the ADAM.
list.4:
Loss function:
The loss function is a measure of the error between the neural network predictions and the real outputs. It is used to optimize the neural network during training and there are different loss functions, such as cross entropy and middle quadratic error.

details-create-and-train-models.title: Create and train model
details-create-and-train-models.text-0: Once all previous fields have been filled we can create the model by pressing the "Create and train model" button.
details-create-and-train-models.text-1:
If we have trained the model with the metric function Accuracy two graphs will appear in the visor. The most relevant to us is that below, since at tensorflow.js, ac and Val_acc are evaluation metrics commonly used in training models of neural networks.
Acc represents the precision (Accuracy) of the model in the training dataset. The precision is defined as the number of correct predictions divided by the total number of predictions.
Val_acc represents the precision of the model in the validation dataset. Validation is used to evaluate the model capacity to generalize new data that has not been seen during training.
details-create-and-train-models.text-2: The validation precision is important to detect the over juste ( over fitting ) of the model, which occurs when the model fits too much to training data and does not generalize well to new data.

details-export-models.title: Export model
details-export-models.text-0: If we have created the model correctly an entry will be added to the table of models generated, we are allowed to export the models generated and save them locally.

details-prediction.title: Clasification
details-prediction.text-0: The final form allows us to select the main characteristics used to determine the class.
details-prediction.text-1: By pressing the "See result" button, the prediction of its output class is obtained from the input characteristics of the element.

app.title: Tool objectives
app.description-1: This application shows some of the most important tasks that artificial neural networks can perform, such as: tabular classification, image classification and object identification.  Networks are artificial intelligence techniques belonging to the field of machine learning, in which models are developed that are trained (or learned) from data sets.
app.description-2: Some of the reasons to work with neural networks are the following:

0.title: Practical applications
0.description: Neural networks are used in a wide variety of applications, from voice recognition and computer vision to data analysis and results prediction. Learning about neural networks can help professionals develop skills that can be applied in fields such as medicine, engineering, data science, marketing and many others.

1.title: Complex problem solution
1.description: Neural networks are useful to solve complex problems that have multiple variables and non -linear relationships. By learning neural networks, professionals can develop more effective solutions for these types of problems and improve the precision and efficiency of their analysis.

2.title: Technological innovation
2.description: Neural networks are an innovative technology that continues to evolve and improve. Learning about neural networks can help professionals stay updated in the latest trends and developments in the field of machine learning and artificial intelligence.

app.description-3: Neural networks are a form of machine learning that mimics the way the human brain works. These networks are designed to continue and improve from past data and experiences, allowing machines to perform complex tasks that were previously impossible or very difficult for traditional programmed systems.
app.description-4: In summary, learning neural networks is important because it can help professionals develop skills that are valuable in a wide variety of fields, solve complex problems more effectively and stay updated in technology and innovation.

tabular-classification.title: Tabular classification
tabular-classification.text-1: Tabular classification is a type of supervised learning in which a set of labeled data is used to train a machine learning model, so that the model can predict the class of new data examples not used in training. In tabular classification, input and output data are represented in the form of a table with rows and columns, where each row represents an instance or example of the data, and each column represents a characteristic or attribute of the data.
tabular-classification.text-2: For example, if you want to predict whether a bank of a bank is solvent or not, the characteristics or attributes that can be used are: income, debts, credit history, age, etc. In the tabular classification, each instance or example of the data set will have values for each of these characteristics and a label (class) that indicates whether the client is solvent or not.
tabular-classification.text-3: Once you have a set of data labeled, an machine learning algorithm is used to train a model that can predict the label of new data sets. This model can be used to perform precise and fast predictions on new data instances.
tabular-classification.text-4: Tabular classification is a very useful technique to solve classification problems in a wide variety of fields, such as medicine, electronic commerce, banking, safety and many others.

text.0: Regression is a statistical analysis method used in machine learning to model the linear relationship between an independent variable and a dependent variable, seeking to find the best straight line that fits the data and allows predictions to be made.
text.1: In regression, data is usually represented as scattered points on a Cartesian plane, where the independent variable is placed on the + b) that minimizes the distance between this line and the data points. Once this equation has been obtained, it can be used to make predictions about future values of the dependent variable based on the values of the independent variable.
text.2: For example, if we are analyzing the relationship between the amount of advertising on a website and the sales of a product, the amount of advertising would be the independent variable, and the sales of the product would be the dependent variable. Regression would help us determine if there is a linear relationship between advertising spend and sales, and if so, it would allow us to predict future sales based on advertising spend.
text.3: Regression is a powerful tool in data analysis and is used in a variety of fields, including economics, social science, medical research, and many other disciplines to understand and predict relationships between variables.

object-identification.title: Object identification
object-identification.text-1: Object identification in neural networks is a technique used in the field of machine learning and computer vision to detect and recognize objects in images or videos. It is an important task in image analysis and is used in applications such as face recognition, real-time object tracking, object classification in medical images, and object detection in autonomous vehicles.
object-identification.text-2: The neural networks used for the identification of objects are deep learning models that are trained in data sets labeled. The training process implies providing the neurons network for a large number of images tagged, and adjusting the weights of connections between neurons so that the network can identify objects in new images with high precision.
object-identification.text-3: Once the neural network has been trained, it is used to identify objects in new images. The network examines the image and, by processing multiple layers, extracts important characteristics that are used to identify objects of interest. Then, the network uses these characteristics to assign a label to each object detected in the image.
object-identification.text-4: In summary, object identification in neural networks is an important technique in computer vision and machine learning that is used to detect and recognize objects in images and videos. It is based on the use of deep neural networks trained on labeled data sets to identify and classify objects in new images with high accuracy.

image-classification.title: Image classification
image-classification.text-1: Image classification is a technique used in neural networks to classify images into different categories or labels. The goal of an image classifier is to take an input image and predict which class it belongs to, based on a set of predefined categories or labels.
image-classification.text-2: In deep learning, image classifiers are based on convolutional neural networks (CNN), which are a specialized architecture to process images. These neural networks have multiple layers and convolution operations that allow them to extract important characteristics from the images, such as edges, shapes and textures.
image-classification.text-3: To train an image classifier, a set of labeled data is used that contains images and their respective class labels. Then, the neural network is trained using this dataset to learn to identify patterns in the images and associate them with the corresponding class labels.
image-classification.text-4: Once the neural network has been trained, it can be used to classify new images in different categories. The image classifier examines the input image and processes it through the neural network to extract important characteristics and predict what class the image belongs.
image-classification.text-5: In short, image classification in neural networks is a technique that uses convolutional neural networks to classify images into different categories or labels. It is based on using a set of labeled data to train the neural network and extracting important features from the images to predict which class a new input image belongs to.

activation-functions.title: Activation functions
activation-functions.text-1: An activation function is a mathematical function used in an artificial neural network to determine the output of a neuron or a set of neurons based on the entry received. The activation function introduces non -linearity in the neural network, allowing the network to learn more complex patterns in the input data. Common examples of activation functions are:

softmax.title: Softmax
softmax.description: Transforms outputs to a representation in the form of probabilities, so that the sum of all probabilities gives 1

sigmoid.title: Sigmoid
sigmoid.description: The sigmoid function transforms the input values into a range between 0 and 1. is commonly used in neural networks for binary classification problems.

characteristics.1: Useful in the output layer of binary classifiers.
characteristics.2: You can suffer the problem of fading of the gradient in deep networks.

hard-sigmoid.title: Hard Sigmoid
hard-sigmoid.description: Hardsigmoid is a simplified version of the sigmoid function used for computational efficiency.

characteristics.0: It is faster to calculate than sigmoid.
characteristics.1: Less soft in the transition between 0 and 1.

relu.title: ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit)
relu.description: The ReLU function is simple and effective when returning zero for negative values and maintaining positive values without changes

relu6.title: ReLU 6
relu6.description: Similar to ReLU, but with a higher limitation of 6 for positive values, which can help avoid the explosion of gradients.

characteristics.1: Useful in networks with unstable gradients.

leaky-relu.title: LeakyReLU
leaky-relu.description: Leaky ReLU is a ReLU variant that allows a small fraction of negative values to pass through the function.

characteristics.0: Mitigate the death problem of neurons compared to reluct.
characteristics.1: It helps maintain information in negative gradients.

elu.title: ELU (Exponential Linear Unit)
elu.description: ELU is a function that resembles ReLU in positive values, but also has a defined gradient for negative values.

characteristics.0: Reduce the problem of fading of the gradient.
characteristics.1: It helps keep more neurons active.

tanh.title: Tanh (hyperbolic tangent)
tanh.description: The hyperbolic tangent function transforms the input values into a range [-1, 1].

characteristics.2: Suffers from fading of the gradient in deep networks.

soft-plus.title: SoftPlus
soft-plus.description: SoftPlus is a soft function that is often used as a soft alternative to reluct.

characteristics.1: It can be useful in generative and regression networks.

mish.title: Mish
mish.description: Mish is a relatively new activation function that combines characteristics of other functions such as hyperbolic tangent and sigmoid function.

characteristics.0: Softness and derivability in its entire range.
characteristics.1: It provides better performance in some applications.

selu.title: SELU (Scaled Exponential Linear Unit)
selu.description: SELU is a function that benefits from specific standardization and can help maintain network stability.

characteristics.0: Autocalibration: stable statistical propagates through the layers.
characteristics.1: It can be useful in networks with self-chire architecture.

activation-function.title: Layer Neurons
activation-function.description: These are the individual units or nodes in a specific layer of the network. Each neuron receives inputs, performs computations and produces an output that is transmitted to the next layer. The number of neurons in a layer can vary and is usually a hyperparameter of the model. The choice of the number of neurons in a layer affects the model's ability to learn representations of the data.

units.title: Layer Activation Function
units.description: At each neuron in a layer of a neural network, an activation function is applied to introduce non-linearity into the model. The activation function determines the output of the neuron as a function of its input and associated weights.

learning-rate.title: Learning Rate
learning-rate.description: The learning rate is a crucial hyperparameter in machine learning algorithms and neural networks. It determines how much the model weights must be updated at each iteration during the training process. A high learning rate can lead to fast convergence, but can result in instability, while a low rate can lead to slow convergence or get stuck in local minima.

number-or-epochs.title: Number of Epochs
number-or-epochs.description: Epochs refer to the number of times the entire training data set has been passed through the model during the training process. A higher number of epochs generally allows the model to fit the data better, but can also lead to overfitting if a certain limit is exceeded.

test-size.title: Test Size
test-size.description: The amount of data that is set aside to evaluate the performance of the model after training. The test set is used to measure the accuracy and overall performance of the model on unseen data.

optimizer.title: Optimiser
optimizer.description: The optimiser is an algorithm that adjusts the parameters of a machine learning model during training. Its goal is to minimise the loss function by updating the model weights efficiently. Examples of common optimisers include Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD), Adam and RMSprop.

loss-function.title: Loss Function
loss-function.description: The loss function is a measure that quantifies how well the model is performing in its predictions. It helps to calculate the difference between the model's predictions and the actual values of the data set. The goal of training is to minimise this function, as a low loss value indicates that the model is a better fit to the data.

metric-function.title: Metric Function
metric-function.description: Unlike the loss function, which is used to optimise the model during training, metric functions are used to evaluate the performance of the model after training. These metrics provide information on accuracy, recall, precision, F1-score, etc., and help to understand how the model performs on specific tasks.

optimization-functions.title: Optimization functions
optimization-functions.text-1: An optimization function is a mathematical technique used to minimize or maximize an objective function. In the context of machine learning, the target functions are usually error functions that measure the discrepancy between the neural network output and the desired output values for a given training dataset.
optimization-functions.text-2: The optimization function adjusts the parameters of the neural network to minimize the objective function and, therefore, improve its ability to make precise predictions in new entry data. Common examples of optimization functions are the descent of the stochastic gradient and the Adam algorithm.

sgd.references:
Stochastic gradient descent
 (Autonomous Technological Institute of Mexico, 2017)
sgd.description:
The descent of the gradient is an algorithm that estimates where a function generates its lower values. In the event that the machine learning model is large -scale this calculation can be very expensive.
                          Because of this, the descent of the stochastic gradient that uses a constant and therefore the number of gradients to be calculated arises.

momentum.description: It is a variation of the previous function. Define a value that accelerates the descent of the gradient if the gradient sign is the same during different times.

adagrad.description: Enter a variation in the concept of learning rate. This scale and adapts this value for each weight with respect to the accumulated gradient in each iteration.

adadelta.description: It is a variation of AdaGrad in which the calculation of the learning rate of each weight is restricted to a fixed size window of the last n gradients instead of doing so with the accumulated gradient of each iteration.

rmsprop.references:
Middle quadratic root propagation
 (Root Mean Square Propagation)
 (Velasco, 2020)
rmsprop.description: This algorithm maintains a different training factor for each dimension, but the scaling of the training factor is done by dividing it by the average of the exponential decline of the square of the gradients.

adam.references:
Adaptive estimation of the mo
 (Adaptive Moment Estimation)
 (Velasco, 2020)
adam.description: It is a combination of AdaGrad and RMSProp . A parameter training factor is maintained and RMSProp is calculated, in addition each training factor is affected by the momentum of the gradient.

adamax.description: It combines momentum and adaptive learning techniques to accelerate convergence during neural network training. It automatically adjusts the learning rate and uses gradient scaling to avoid divergence issues.

text.0: In machine learning, a loss function (also called cost function) is a measure that quantifies the discrepancy between the predicted exit by a model and the real or desired output. In other words, the loss function measures how well the model conforms to training data.
text.1: The objective of an machine learning algorithm is to minimize the loss function, which means finding the model set of the model that best suits training data. Therefore, the choice of loss function is very important, since it can affect the model ability to correctly learn patterns in the data and make precise predictions in new data.
text.2: In tensorflow.js there are different loss functions and the application of each of them depends on the type of problem we want to face. Some examples are shown below:

AbsoluteDifference.description: Calculates the distance to the target in absolute value.

ComputeWeightedLoss.description: Calculate the weighted loss between two given tensioners.

CosineDistance.description: Calculate the loss by applying the cosine of the distance between two tensioners.

HingeLoss.description: Calculate the loss of hinge between two tensioners. It applies in classification problems.

HuberLoss.description: Calculate the loss caused by the estimation procedure.

LogLoss.description: logloss or Logistic loss is a convex function that grows linearly for negative numbers and makes it recently sensitive to atypical values. Calculate the logarithmic loss between two tensioners.

MeanSquaredError.description: Calculate in a geometric way the square distance to the target, this function is used in regression problems.

CategoricalCrossEntropy.description: It measures the distance between probability distributions. It is applied in networks whose output layer is a probability.

SigmoidCrossEntropy.description: It is a variant of the categorical function categorical categorical, in this case, it calculates the loss in a value between 0 and 1.

SoftmaxCrossEntropy.description: A combination of the functions Softmax and crossenterpy calculating the loss of the network is applied.

metric-functions.title: Metric functions
metric-functions.text-1: They are used to evaluate the performance of the neural network model in a test data set. The metric function takes the predictions made by the model and compare them with the real values of the test data to determine the precision of the model.
metric-functions.text-2: There are different types of metric functions that can be used in a neural network, depending on the type of problem that is being addressed. For example, for a problem of binary classification, precision (Accuracy) could be used as metric, while for a regression problem the average quadratic error could be used (Mean Squared Error).
metric-functions.text-3: In summary, a metric function is an important tool to assess the ability of a neural network to perform precise predictions in a test dataset and to help adjust the model parameters to improve its performance.
metric-functions.text-4: We mainly use the accuracy function. In multi-label classification, this function calculates subset precision: the predicted set of labels for a sample must exactly match the corresponding set of labels in y

BinaryAccuracy.description: Calculate the frequency with which the predictions coincide with binary labels.

BinaryCrossentropy.description: It is the negative average of the logarithm of the predicted chances that have been corrected.

CategoricalAccuracy.description: Calculate the frequency with which the predictions coincide with the ONE-Hot labels.

CategoricalCrossentropy.description: Calculate the crossed entropy metric between labels and predictions.

CosineProximity.description: Calculate between labels and predictions the proximity cosine. Normally negative values are obtained.

MeanAbsoluteError.description: In statistics, it is a measure of the difference between two continuous variables, applied to machine learning models These variables are labels and predictions.

MeanAbsolutePercentageError.description: In the same way that Mean absolute error calculates the difference between labels and predictions, but in this case with a percentage.

MeanSquaredError.description: Determine the average quadratic error between labels and predictions.
